lessonOutcomes.outcome: Students can recognise and name six toys (balloon, bike, doll, train, robot, teddy bear) when listening and looking at visual prompts.
supportStrategies: (Vocab) Show toy flashcards, say the word, students repeat. Then ask: “Which one is the robot?”
stretchStrategies: Use a covered flashcard game: hide part of a toy flashcard behind paper on the board. Students guess what it is using “Is it a ___?” until they find the right toy.

supportStrategies: (Speaking) Model with flashcard: “What’s this?” – “It’s a balloon.” Students practise with 3–5 items.

lessonOutcomes.outcome: Students can ask and answer questions using the target structure “What’s this?” / “It’s a ___” to talk about toys.
supportStrategies: (Grammar) Write full structure on board: “What’s this? – It’s a ___.” Students practise with toys in SB.

items: VYL: colours do not map onto one another (blue/green = blue)

In Vietnamese, final consonants are 'held in' – you don't actually hear them released. But in English, the final consonant of cat, top, rock, and so on are released with a puff of air. Make sure you are aware of this difference.
Do not exist in standard Vietnamese, written or spoken. The hardest part for YLs is learning to pronounce them naturally: there's a dog rather than there is a dog.
